newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Diplomats see no end to EU "company statute" row.
newsitem.headline: Diplomats see no end to EU "company statute" row.

text.p: European Union social affairs ministers will try this weekend to break a long-standing deadlock over plans to allow firms to set up as European companies, but diplomats say chances of progress are slim.

"I'm not sure I see a breakthrough," a British diplomat said, predicting the informal talks in Echternach, Luxembourg, on Friday and Saturday would reaffirm the conflict between London and Bonn -- despite Britain's change of government.

The European Commission's proposal for a European company statute, designed to make life easier and cheaper for industry by eliminating the need to set up a network of costly subsidiaries, has been deadlocked for more than 20 years.

The main stumbling block has been provisions on worker participation in company decisions, with Germany promoting its own system of 50-50 "co-determination" between employees and managers and Britain arguing there should be no mandatory rules.

The Commission said in May it saw chances of ending the row in the form of proposals from a high-level expert group headed by Etienne Davignon, the chairman of Belgian holding company Societe Generale and a former European commissioner.
The Davignon group suggested unions and employers should try to agree on the level of worker involvement in individual firms.
If they failed, a set of reference rules would apply, forcing firms to give workers' representatives a fifth of board seats.

The proposal, which the British diplomat said was largely intended to address Bonn's fear "that firms would be able to wriggle out of their co-determination (obligations) by setting up as a European company", has not fully satisfied either side.
"The rule that one fifth of (board members) should be employees' representatives...is not satisfactory because it doesn't go as far as our own system," a German diplomat said.

British diplomats, for their part, argue that the Davignon proposals go too far, forcing the hand of firms operating in countries that do not have a tradition of worker participation, such as Britain and Ireland.

Davignon's idea of imposing mandatory minimum rules would undermine the very useful idea of a European company statute because it would make it unattractive to companies in some EU countries, one said.
